Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 18-Oct-20 01:03 PM
He didn't know what to say. Perhaps he ought to simply shut his mouth and not talk. Ever. That much he'd learned early on into his captaincy. I shouldn't be acting this way - and I should not have invalidated how you feel. I'm..." Come on. You know apologies alone won't fix this hot mess you've driven yourself into, you dumb bean. "...sorry. I'll improve... become a better person. Though of course I will let what I do going forward speak for me rather than what I say."
Lt. Cmdr. Amanda Higgins 18-Oct-20 01:17 PM
"The blessing and the curse of being a captain is putting your crew before you. My roommate at the academy was trying to get into command and spoke of that often," She said, her voice very soft, letting the weariness of the past few years seep into the open. She spoke like reciting from a textbook. " Being an xo is harder still, because while you speak for the crew, you also speak for the captain. You have the crew's needs in front of you as well as the captain's. I think I got all that correct. I don't blame you for being upset about what happened to you Commander, I really don't. Killing isn't something to be taken lightly and just passed over. But if I may, let me give you a slice of advice. I'm not a Captain, nor do I really want to be. But I have a lot of captain's knowledge stuck in my borg brain. I'm happy to talk to you and listen to you, the crew is too. This is a fine ship and a great crew, one of the best I've served with. But, you need to realize that we're also people with our own stuff we go through. Every single person here from the captain to the cadets have lives and personalities and... Individuality. We aren't drones right? So, find out what makes us tick, learn about your crew and value them. Don't dismiss their troubles just because you have your own. Sympathize, empathize and help. You'll work through their stuff and almost invariably you'll work through yours. And that's the measure of a good friend Dune."

Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 31-Oct-20 01:01 PM
Having come back to his quarters a few hours earlier and gotten some sleep (thankfully uninterrupted save Bingsu licking him awake), he was now standing in front of the bathroom mirror trying on different outfits. Several already lay discarded off to the side; if one looked they'd spot the robes of a medieval knight, a small crown, a jester's hat (yes, really, he'd tried that) and a clergyman's garb among other things. Most things had simply looked too big or too silly on him given his scrawny frame... except this outfit. Picking up the wide-brimmed hat in front of him, he carefully placed it on his head - and to his relief it did not sink down and cover his eyes. At last. He studied the rest of his costume: brown hooved boots with spurs, black vest, long blue jeans, leather belt, empty leather sidearm holster, long, brown coat, light grey undershirt and a red bandanna round the neck... and the hat of course. He'd read a little about the alleged 'cowboys' of human past and, oddly, found it amusing that their clothing found its place in popular culture centuries after their way of life had died out.

Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 02-Nov-20 12:16 AM
The PADD in his hands dropped to the floor - along with the Kelpien himself, into the sofa, thankfully - hands shaking and eyes wet with stinging tears. And there she went. He'd known that her days were numbered. It was inevitable, this tragic day. Somehow, amidst the abject sorrow there was a sense of relief and, somehow, joy - that things had, at last, come to an end for her. For one who had given so much life, so much peace to others, all that now returned in full - or in abundance, in the life beyond death. He allowed himself to sob quietly for a few more moments before straightening up, wiping his tears and heading to the door. As much as he would have loved to sit there and bawl, in the here and now he had a crew who was grieving as he was, and he had a job to do.

Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 07-Nov-20 02:28 PM
The groceries were swiftly put away and a shower taken, and into dress uniform it was for him - somehow he felt that perhaps the uniform had grown heavier. Perhaps it was the weight on his shoulders; the task of somehow or other summarizing and doing justice to Phenna's life. A life lived out fully and wholly, spent giving and giving and giving of love, tenderness and warmth... until she could give no more of herself. Words alone, no matter how grandiose and numerous, would never adequately do a life of such magnitude justice. And here he was, about to attempt that very task. Oh boy. The speech was prepared, of course, typed out verbatim on his PADD, which he accessed now, perusing the lines of text, expression grim. So many lines, so many words... Phenna wouldn't have liked that, he thought. For someone with such a storied lifetime, she'd lived simply - that much was apparent in each and every interaction with her. Grandiose speeches thus did not befit the occasion, for she would have wanted it to be as simple as possible. After all, in her own eyes, she was a counsellor, simply doing her job. He knew then what to do.
4
A simple eulogy, without repeating himself or going in circles. That would suffice. His thanks - and possibly by extension the crew's - did not need to be brought across thusly. And he only had a matter of hours. He got to work immediately. Time was of the essence.

My crew is scared, as expected. Many of them did not enter Starfleet service to go into war or combat, I am sure, but to open their eyes to the wider universe beyond the boundaries of home. I would not wish the trauma, mental and emotional, that war brings on anyone.
>
On another much lighter and friendlier note I hope those pasta and pesto recipes I sent to you last time have been useful. I've attached a few more herewith for your reference and use - when it is convenient, of course. Maybe you might want to try carbonara sauce? I've attached a recipe for that as well. It can be quite addictive, however, or so I've learned; I simply hope that your galley chef has enough eggs for when that happens. If that happens, rather.
>
I've been trying to relax, take my mind off our immediate pressing concern - after all it cannot be all-consuming - but it is difficult. I've begun to cook a little more with my partner. I find it quite relaxing in fact, and as I recall, I still owe you dinner. Next time we meet, perhaps, if it is convenient.
>
But I shall be utterly honest. Lhaesar, my friend, I am afraid. We are no longer battling Klingons and Breen; our opponents this time are far more ancient and far more powerful. The Iconian Whole and the first Iconian War were what precipitated the precursor to the Alliance, as you may know; I fear that they may be the ones who succeed in tearing it apart again - literally. This time there may be not enough of the Alliance left once their vengeance has been enacted.
4
Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 17-Jan-21 05:29 AM
This time there is no more World Heart to return from which to form an accord of peace. There is just us and the Whole, and this time no aid from the Krenim and the members of the Delta Alliance. This time I fear that T'Ket and her sisters, if they are indeed those who started the events that made this happen, will accept no compromise.
>
Stay safe, my friend. Please. If I do not survive this ordeal, just know that I love you. As a friend. I cannot thank you enough for being there for me through all these years and for constantly reminding me that I am more than my uniform, rank and position. Don't stop. Don't you ever stop. To anyone you consider a friend, family - or more.
>
Nonetheless let us look to the stars. If every one of them is a possibility, one of them is surely one where at the end of it all, things turn out well. Let us look towards that possibility, shall we?
>
Love, Duney

Commander T'Svai 21-Feb-21 03:39 PM
Though T'Svai had been to her quarters a handful of times since Commander Dunamis had departed, for some reason they all felt like the first. There was a legacy in this room. That's what it was. Illogical as it was to wax poetic, the wisdom of those who had come before seem to lurk in the corners and, at night, in the places where the light of the distant starscape shone softly through the window and scattered on the floor. Even having moved her personal effects in, it felt like stepping into a museum, and the general aesthetic of Vulcan decor did not at all help that illusion. However, unlike the first few times, the illusion of loftiness faded very quickly, because she was growing increasingly comfortable with the idea of claiming that space as her own. Over the past week she'd managed to move her decor where she'd liked it, find Kov's new favorite spot, and get several recommendations from her friends on the K'Warko on what to do with the extra space, none of which had been good.
